lines: MR STELIOS THRASYVOULOU
PRESIDENT:  Mr Thrasyvoulou, thank you very much for coming
back.  I just remind you that the oath you took on
Thursday remains in force.
WITNESS:  Yes, sir.
Cross-examination by MR CATCHPOLE (continued)
MR CATCHPOLE:  Good morning, Mr Thrasyvoulou.
I'm afraid we have still got quite a bit to cover,
but just so you're clear what we're dealing with, I'm
really just focusing on briefly through the events of
the supplemental agreement, but then into the events
surrounding the termination and the bond call.  That's
what we're focusing on today.
Can we start, please, in February 2021, orientate
ourselves.  This is just in the run-up to the
supplemental agreement between the JV and the employer.
If we could look in your second witness statement,
paragraph 8.7, B3-11.  You're saying effectively
Specon's position had got significantly worse
from October.  You say:
"Unfortunately the cashflow situation ... got worse.
From around October 2020 through October 2021, Specon's
Interim Payment Applications were being valued by SBJV
at nil or in a negative amount, and SBJV virtually
stopped making payments to Specon through the formal
payment mechanism under the Subcontract.  Instead, SBJV
resorted to drip-feeding amounts to Specon through
ad hoc payments to keep the Project going and at the
request of Specon to pay amounts on its behalf (as
Specon was not receiving any payments through the formal
payment mechanism)."
You say that that was set out in your letter of
7 April, and then we come to a WhatsApp which we will
look at in a moment.
Can I just -- I have dealt with the interim payment
applications with some of the other witnesses, but
I just want to give you a flavour of what's actually
happening.
Could we just have a look at IPC number 52.  It's
This is the February certificate, 25 February 2021.
I just want you to look at what's actually happening.
The top box is the Arcadis certificate and any penalties
being deducted for failure to complete NCRs.  It starts
off with a negative valuation, minus 2 million.  Do you
see that?
A.  Yes, I do.
Q.  Largely, that's because the adjustments being made by
Arcadis are, in this particular one, a substantial
adjustment for the materials on site?
A.  That's right, yeah.
Q.  Nothing to do with the JV to get to that negative
valuation?
A.  It would appear so.
Q.  On this particular one, the JV are -- it's a negative
valuation -- not seeking to claim back any work by the
contractor, which is the entry under "Total retention",
nor, right at the bottom, any contra charges.  So the
basic position is that it's Arcadis' valuation that is
resulting either in a very low or a negative valuation;
is that fair?
A.  Bear with me, please; have a look at the certificate.
(Pause)
This certificate is purely on the gross level, yes.
Q.  Then if we go to IPC 53, which is B35.126-1, what we see
is the pattern gets worse.  If we could just expand that
slightly so we can see the entries more clearly.  That's
enough.  Thank you.
Again, the Arcadis valuation is now at a minus
8.3 million, and that's because the value of works that
have been certified is --
PRESIDENT:  Sorry, Mr Catchpole, our transcript seems to
have stopped.
MR CATCHPOLE:  Right.  Sorry.
TECHNICIAN:  Yes, sir, let me check.  (Pause)
Sir, can we have five minutes?
PRESIDENT:  All right.  We'll break for five minutes.
(A short break)
PRESIDENT:  Now, your challenge, Mr Catchpole, is to
remember what question you had asked.
MR CATCHPOLE:  Sorry, Mr Thrasyvoulou.  That's very
disruptive and it's not very fair on you as a witness.
Coming back, this is the March certificate and we
see a similar pattern.  Do you see that?  Arcadis'
valuation is minus 8.3 million, but of which there's
a 4.2 million penalty that's been applied for not
completing NCRs.
A.  The 4.2 million related to non-conforming works, yes.
I remember that.
Q.  But the fundamental point is the negative valuation,
certainly from this point on, is being driven by Arcadis
and/or with contribution from the penalty applied
because you haven't cleared outstanding NCRs?
A.  There's a reason for this negative valuation, sir.  The
minus 8 million relates to the measured work as per the
contract value that presumably Arcadis had to
administer.  So if you don't mind, would it be possible
to scroll a little bit further down on this page?
Q.  Yes, of course.
A.  Slightly more, please.
So as you can see there, estimated subcontract
amount -- and this is, by the way, a month after the
SBJV signed the 1.4 billion, I understand, claims
agreement on the supplementary agreement, our
subcontract value is still 700 million.  So Arcadis
presumably were working on a different metric to apply
the percentage work done on the contract leading to
negative valuations.
This was made even worse.  If you look at, in the
middle of that table, there's a deduction by the SBJV of
14 million for works, presumably paid on our behalf,
obviously that would have been subject to an audit at
the time by the site, but it led to a minus 20 million
valuation on a significantly lower number on our
subcontract works.
Q.  Just to be fair, what's under the supplemental agreement
that had been agreed between SBJV and the employer, the
value of the subcontract works for you was about
750 million, wasn't it?
A.  No, it wasn't, sir.  That was -- I've seen that
statement made by the SBJV.  We were not privy to the
discussions the SBJV had with the client.  I, for the
first time, have seen the value in the supplementary
agreement number 1 for the SBJV the other day when it
was disclosed to the tribunal.
Q.  Anyway, the pattern, however, I'm suggesting to you,
what we see in the certificates is that there's the
Arcadis valuations, which from -- throughout, really,
are either low or themselves negative each month, and
then, as you rightly point to, an increasing debt to the
JV through works done on behalf of SBJV and the
contracharges for paying your suppliers, specialist
subcontractors.  Is that fair, is that --
A.  No, sir, that's not fair.  That's purely a mathematical
calculation based on the fact that the subcontract
amount was significantly lower than what it should be
and what it actually -- what it subsequently was.
Q.  Right.  But in terms of the valuation that's driving
that, that's coming from Arcadis; is that right?
A.  The percentage progress is coming from Arcadis.  It's
based on the value given to them presumably by the SBJV,
sir.  They did not have the revised subcontract value
which was subsequently discussed in our supplementary
agreement, for example, as an interim.
Q.  Mr Thrasyvoulou, Arcadis are the employer's consultant,
aren't they?
A.  Correct.
Q.  And Arcadis, the process is that Arcadis are valuing the
work, including your work, and then they will certify to
the JV and the JV passes on that certification to the
relevant trade subcontractor?
A.  Excluding claims, sir.  Excluding claims.
Q.  But the value is coming from -- the fundamental
valuation is coming from Arcadis.  That's the
starting point?
A.  The percentages, yes, correct.
Q.  This has got nothing to do with us certifying at nil.
This is because Arcadis have certified it either at nil
or negative as a starting point.  That's right, isn't
it?
A.  Sir, I believe I have explained that.  It has to do with
the overall value.
Q.  What I'm suggesting to you is that what the pattern is
also showing is not that the SBJV is drip-feeding money,
as you rather pejoratively suggest; we are actually
supporting -- we are paying just about everything Specon
is having to expend in order to try and progress its
works; is that fair?
A.  The SBJV at this stage were paying on our behalf because
that was the mechanism they were utilising on the
contract whilst they had already a 1.4 billion
adjustment in their contract value as at the date of
this certificate.
Q.  They did not have, Mr Thrasyvoulou, a 1.4 billion
adjustment in the contract value of the M2/M3 works.
A.  Not in the M2/M3 works, sir, you're correct: in the
overall -- in their contract value.
Q.  Those costs that they are expending from their own money
on your behalf, continue to rise exponentially through
2021; is that right?
A.  Through the process of meeting the milestones, yes, they
had to make additional payments, because that was the
only mechanism available to us for project payments at
the time.
Q.  No, with the greatest respect, Mr Thrasyvoulou, you
couldn't pay to progress the works and you were asking
the SBJV to pay for you?
A.  Sir, the last time we received a payment in our bank
from the SBJV was probably a year earlier than the date
of this certificate.
Q.  You could not pay out of your funds or out of your
borrowings or your financing to progress the works and
you were relying on and demanding that the JV paid for
you.  That is the factual position, isn't it?
A.  That's the position we agreed with SBJV for the sake of
the works.
Q.  Right.  B35.1 --
MR STEWART:  If you're moving on, Mr Catchpole, at some
point I wouldn't mind seeing a copy of what you referred
to as the Arcadis valuation --
MR CATCHPOLE:  They're behind these --
MR STEWART:  They're behind these, are they?
MR CATCHPOLE:  In general.  Not always.  I can show you one,
for example, but --
MR STEWART:  The reference will do fine, at some convenient
point.
MR CATCHPOLE:  Generally there are sheets behind all of
these.  This is the top sheet and one can then go back
to the summary.
MR STEWART:  Thank you.
MR CATCHPOLE:  I'll get the reference rather than trying to
do it on ...
Just to get a flavour of what's going on, B35.128-1,
please.  Next month, same pattern.  This is now negative
5 million certification, but if one looks down, the
contracharges are now 14 million in this month, and the
net amount due is 60 million.  In other words, what
we're seeing is an increasing, ever increasing amounts
that the JV are paying on your behalf to fund the works
going forward; is that fair?
A.  Sir, it's the same principle.  Subcontract value still
unchanged two months after the supplementary agreement.
Q.  Well, that's because you were trying to negotiate
a different amount, weren't you?
A.  But still meeting the milestones during that time, sir.
Q.  We've dealt with that with some others.
Can we just look at another example.  B35.132-1.
This is an advance payment, in effect.  On account
payment.  Do you see that?  15 million.
Do you recall that this related to: you had to come
to the JV in April asking for 15 million of funds from
them directly, to stop your bankers closing your
accounts, because you had exceeded your overdraft?
A.  No, it wasn't exactly like that.  We did request the
15 million, of course we did.  We needed to maintain the
banking facilities going.  It wasn't about an overdraft.
Again, it's the same matter relating to the subcontract
value.  The bank was funding the project and the bank
expected, as a natural progression, to see changes in
the subcontract value due to either approval or
variations or claims as we went along, and this did not
happen.
Q.  Could we just briefly look at P5 and then page 30 within
that document.  P5, just the covering letter first,
page 1.
This is a letter, 20 April 2021.  This is part of
a very substantial request for payments to the JV, total
of 33.65 million.  Within it, if we turn to page 2, we
can see one item, "Appendix 3 - Bank Charges",
15.3 million AED.  Then if we go forward to page 30.
It's a letter of 15 February 2021 from HSBC to
yourselves:
"Further to our discussion on 14th February ...
where we discussed your current situation with the Bank,
we ... wish to bring your attention that we are
concerned about the following.
"That the total overdue exposure [under] the Import
line is currently approx AED 15.33M.
"That the earliest overdue exposure is nearing
90 days.
"While we do understand that there have been some
dialogue on going with the main contractor and the
paymaster regarding the final settlement of the project
value, we will require for you to settle the earliest
dues (as detailed below) on or before 18th February ...
to avoid a downgrade internally and on Central Bank."
And the total is 15.34.
That's right, isn't it, you hadn't been able to meet
that deadline and you came to the JV asking for the JV
to pay this to avoid a downgrade of your accounting
status, both internally at HSBC and on the Central Bank;
is that right?
A.  I don't recall when the 15 million was paid, but I can
see from here, that HSBC letter, it's pretty clear what
it says.  I believe the downgrade was averted because we
ultimately were downgraded in October, post the bond
call.
Q.  The downgrade was averted because the JV, out of its own
funds, paid you 15 million?
A.  It's not out of their own funds, sir.  It's out of the
funds on the contract and that was administered in the
way they were administering the contract.
Q.  Could we please come back to your witness statement,
second witness statement, paragraph 8.2, B3-12.  8.8,
sorry.
We looked at 8.7.  Now you're dealing
with March/April and you say this:
"As Specon was reaching a breaking point, I recall
reaching out to Alistair Mitchell, MEP Director for
projects at ICD ... to explain how bad the situation had
gotten and requesting the Owner's intervention,
including by WhatsApp messages on 7 April..."
Pausing there, I suggest to you that based on what
we've just seen, and what we discussed on Friday, you
hadn't just reached breaking point by March/April; you
were effectively unable to fund your operations going
forward.  Is that fair?
A.  On the contract, sir, yes.
Q.  You say this: there's an email that you -- sorry,
a WhatsApp, and what you're saying to Mr Mitchell
is: sorry to bother you -- could we expand in so we can
read it, please, for people who are rather ancient like
myself:
"I hope you're well.
"Sorry to bother you again about this matter but the
situation is getting worse on site (RAP).
"Despite agreeing in principle how to proceed we are
still receiving zero certificates.  Following the
3 zeros for Oct, Nov, and Dec we now received a zero
for Jan and a minus(!!) for 2M for Feb.
"It is impossible to operate/perform/meet any
targets as it is now 7 months (since the Sept
certificate) to receive a single AED..."
Factually, is that right: it was impossible for you
to operate on the project because you hadn't got the
money to do so?
A.  Yes, sir, it was.
Q.  "I am really lost for words to describe what is going
on.  I cannot understand the strategy adopted by the
SBJV.  What are they trying to do here?!
"My Father tried to call Mr Galadari yesterday and
we wrote numerous letters to the SBJV to alert them to
this nonsense but we are getting nowhere ...
"I will send you the latest letter via WhatsApp that
summarises the abysmal cash situation generated by this
treatment.
"Would appreciate any assistance.
"We will not be able to meet the targets without at
least 10-12M per month and are fast running out of
months."
Is this right: your assessment at that time was you
needed 10 to 12 million dirhams a month in order simply
to fund the works going forward?
A.  That's correct.
Q.  It's also right that the Arcadis valuations from October
through to -- not the JV's, the Arcadis valuation -- had
not approached 10 to 12 million in any of those months?
A.  Because they were basing the percentage on a lower
number.
Q.  Just factually, the Arcadis valuations and the
certificates had not even approached those figures?
A.  As I explained, yes, they didn't.
Q.  You obviously are blaming the JV for doing that.  Could
we just -- I'm going to suggest to you that isn't
a particularly fair representation of what had been
going on, because you had been begging the JV to pay
your salaries, your labour costs, provide labour,
provide materials, pay your creditors, pay your -- not
at this stage, but you were about to ask them to pay for
your bank.  And they are responding to that.  They are
giving you money?
A.  Sir, Alistair Mitchell, who was the representative of
ICD for MEP on the contract, was well aware of the
certificates that we received, so everything you showed
me earlier on, Alistair had copies.  I even gave him
copies when we met.  There was full transparency on the
way our works were certified.  Our contract was not
amended, though.
Q.  M274, please.  Just going to go back slightly in time.
This is just before -- M274.  This is just before the JV
are entering into the supplemental agreement it had with
the employer.  Mr Patze is emailing you on 9 February:
"Please find in attachment the value as per the
proposal of Pierre ..."
On the Specon final account.
So this is, he's sending to you the employer Omnium
valuation of the final account based on claims including
prolongation claims up to February and the variation
claims up to the end of August, I think?
A.  Sir, Pierre is the chief operating officer of Besix.
Q.  Well, can we just go forward, please.  If you go to
MR STEWART:  I don't think that exists.
MR CATCHPOLE:  Sorry, no, it should be the attachment.
Sorry, M275.
The attachment to that email gives a breakdown of
contract value M2/M3, contract value M2F, client
variations, 59 million, coming up to a subtotal of 702.
And then item 4 was compensation for claims,
48.3 million, a figure that we will now be familiar
with.
That 48.3 million was, you were being told, the
employer's assessment, Omnium's assessment, of the
various claims that you had put up during late
October -- sorry, late 2020?
A.  No, sir, that's not correct.
Q.  I have to suggest it clearly is, and that's what it
always was.  Indeed, if we go forward, please, to --
there's then a period of negotiation.  You don't accept
that, but if we could go to D10370-1.  It should be
11 February.  Sorry, 11 February.
The email from you responding to this, "Specon Final
Account":
"Dear Bernard
"The AED 825M discussed almost a year ago ... was
for a quick settlement at that time with the information
we had available at that time.  The Client opted for
a different approach which was to appoint consultants,
audit the costs, review the claims, discuss all
variations and PS adjustments through road maps etc."
That's the process that Omnium were involved in and
you were directly involved in?
A.  For the main contractor, sir.
Q.  Listen to the question.  You also, Specon, were directly
involved in that process and putting together the
information that the main contractor was passing up, as
part of your claims to the employer.  That's right,
isn't it?
A.  Sir, the interaction with Omnium that we had was one or
two audits in our office of the cost system of Specon
relating to how much money we've spent on prelims and
labour.  We didn't know what Omnium will do with those
numbers or the discussions they were having upstream
with the SBJV.  We were never privy to those
discussions.
Q.  Mr Thrasyvoulou, Specon was being required to prepare
and submit its claims, prolongation, extensions of time,
so prolongation costs, extension of time, disruption,
additional engineering costs, and wild air claims, plus
the variations.  Do you recall that?
A.  To the SBJV, sir.
Q.  Knowing full well that what was being required by the
employer, it was being passed up to Omnium for an
assessment, because the employer wanted to get to
a valuation for the final account at that point with
a line in the sand.  Is that right?
A.  For the main contractor, yes.
Q.  But not for you?
A.  No.  Otherwise we would have been involved in
discussions.
Q.  Right.  Then you say this:
"As a result, variations and PS adjustments ended up
at 145M when we properly analysed them."
So you're saying you had no idea what they were
doing, but -- your assessment was 145, but you didn't
know why you were assessing it; is this right?
A.  No, this is our variations and provisional sum
adjustments.
Q.  Right:
"The settlement numbers offered for the claims/EOT
are not far off..."
So that's saying, as I understand it, the
48.3 million, not far off whatever the claims and the
EOT are; is that right?
A.  Sir, the sentence also continues to say:
"... they need to be adjusted to allow for
additional 6 months --"
Q.  I can read the rest, but that is -- you are agreeing
that the 48.3 million is not far off for the claims that
you have submitted up to, subject to, the additional six
months for completion; is that right?
A.  Sir, this is just taking my words out of context.  We
were discussing a supplementary agreement following
their supplementary agreement.
Q.  No, you weren't.
A.  I have made very clear in this email, albeit it was
superseded by what we signed, that it was short of six
months.
Q.  But you are saying, in terms, these are your words, you
are agreeing -- you understand that the 48.3 is the
valuation of your claim that have been submitted,
subject to that caveat, and you are admitting that they
are, quote, "not far off".  Now, is that factually right
or wrong?
A.  Sir, this is part of the discussions we had which
ultimately ended up in the document we signed on the
7th, I believe, of June 2021.
Q.  Is it factually right that as at 11 February, your
assessment was that the claim for 48.3 million was not
far off an appropriate settlement for the claims and EOT
including prolongation costs that you had submitted?
A.  Sir, if you add six months of prelims then we're not far
off, as I said in that statement.
Q.  So if you add on another six months.  So the answer to
my question is: yes, the 48.3 million is not far off as
an assessment for the claims you had submitted, but
you've got to take account of the other prelims?
A.  Six months, which is approximately -- we were on
3 million a month, I presume, or 3 and a half, so you're
talking about around 70, which is what we wanted.
Q.  We're agreed, Mr Thrasyvoulou.  I'm not disputing -- I'm
not suggesting to you it includes the six months that
you're referring to?
A.  Okay, that's fine.
Q.  Then you went on:
"Our issue as mentioned many times is the
unacceptable shortfall in the proposed AED 11M out of
AED 48M (22%) of varied works, and procurement PS's
which have not been properly assessed by the Client."
If I understand it correctly, that's the sort of
29 million-ish, plus the prelims, effectively, that
ultimately are the matters you need to have referred or
want to have referred to the third party expert a bit
further down the line; is that right?
A.  On the third party expert, our view of what needed to be
referred I believe is set out clearly in the draft
document that was sent to Mr Refki of the SBJV and is
part of the pleading documents and we can refer to that
if you want.
Q.  Can we come back to the WhatsApp we looked at.  That was
the beginning of April.  I just wanted to look at what
was underlying that.  D11155-1.
This was shortly before the WhatsApp is sent.
I think it may actually be the document that's in your
WhatsApp, but I couldn't quite work it, but it's
31 March 2021.  You're writing to say:
"We write to express our concerns --"
No, it's not the one that you sent.  But:
"We write to express our concerns with the speed
with which matters are progressing in relation to
resolving the financial state of the contract in
relation to our M2/M3 subcontract package.
"Further to the meeting between our respective
Senior Management/Boards on the 18th March ... yet to
receive [any] payment work to formalise the
agreed-in-principle settlement/framework ...
"This is leading to serious issues as communicated
to you (and your team) on numerous occasions both
verbally and in writing, and in particular [in relation]
to:
"Regularising our banking facilities.
"Paying salaries and wages.
"Paying our supply chain.
"Paying our Subcontractors.
"Igniting and issuing new LCs; and
"Planning our cash flow and works properly."
You say:
"In view of the above, and the fact that we are
conscious time is of the essence, we propose what we now
see as the only way forward at this critical stage of
the project that will allow us to meet our deliverables,
all of which is in line with the agreed settlement
process/framework agreement."
If I may summarise, effectively, you have reached
the point where you cannot operate anything that you
need for the purposes of running the project and you're
now making a proposal that you see as the only way to
enable you to continue; is that right?
A.  May I see the date of the letter again, please?
Q.  Yes, of course.  It's at the top of the page.
31 March 2021.
A.  End of March was the period where we were -- what's the
word ...
We were all trying to meet the milestones at the
time -- "frantically" was the word I was looking for,
trying to meet the milestones at the site and our
project director made a suggestion here in terms of how
to get money to progress and keep meeting those
milestones.
That was done in parallel to our negotiations with
the SBJV's senior management to resolve our
supplementary agreement.  It was at the same time.
Q.  I'm sorry if I'm labouring the point.  The point I'm
putting to you is you cannot, you Specon, simply cannot
pay any of the basics that are listed under those bullet
points that are necessary to run the project.  And you
are saying now, at the end of March: this is the only
way we can meet our deliverables based on whatever this
proposal is?
A.  Sir, I think I made that also clear earlier on when
I said -- when we were not receiving money in our
account.  So of course it was impossible.
Q.  You're agreed?
A.  Yes, I agree, that was the only way available to us to
keep going at the time on the project.
Q.  Could we please go to page 3.
What you then go on to say is that:
"The following table identifies what we consider is
the minimum requirement in terms of monthly payment
allocation to meet the December 2021 targets all within
the principles of the settlement framework agreement."
Then you set out amounts received, and the headline
amount that you need to receive is 825 million by
2 December; is that correct?
A.  That's correct.
Q.  So the balance -- sorry?
A.  Sorry, I was going to say that's correct and that was
subsequently in the supplementary agreement.
Q.  Exactly.
A.  Excluding the third party discussion.
Q.  And that's what I'm coming to, and hopefully
short-circuit the supplementary agreement.
A.  That's fine.
Q.  So the balance to be paid to Specon, 85 million, and
then you identify in the table headed "Cash payments
required as a min to meet the plan", and it's
85.6 million, which is the 10 to 12 million you were
referring to Mr Mitchell?
A.  Sir, that's right.
Q.  That, as you absolutely rightly say, is then what forms
the basis of the supplemental agreement.  I don't want
to oversimplify it, but in very simple terms, the
employer valuation had been effectively 750 million all
in, but you needed to get to 825.  So what you agree,
the JV agreed on an interim basis to credit your final
account with 75 million, which got you up to the 825.
That's the starting point.  Yes?
A.  Well, I don't exactly agree with everything you said,
sir.  The 825 is one of the numbers that is central to
meeting our --
Q.  Sorry.  I'm taking it too slowly in each stage.
Part of it is, there is: we agree immediately,
interim, on account, 75 million.  That gets you to
your 825.
A.  Yes.
Q.  There is then a dispute between the JV and Specon about
the value of the claims as to what that 75 goes to.
You're saying we should be entitled not to 75, but to
100.  The JV says minimum -- sorry, maximum you're
entitled to is 34?
A.  Correct.
Q.  It's that, sorting out where you are on that delta,
which was going to be the subject of the third party
process?
A.  Correct, and if I may add, another 45 million variation
submitted to the SBJV and client in relation to
post-30 August matters.
Q.  But those are matters which are going to go up, to the
extent they are pass-through claims, for the client to
have to value and then pass back down in the normal way?
A.  It's works that needed to be executed by 2 December, so
you don't -- you know, that needed to be expedited one
way or another.
Q.  Just in terms of the process, because it was work that
